name: butter production, from cream, from cow milk | buttermilk, from cow milk | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/11119/documentation

Butter is a dairy product made by churning fresh or fermented cream or milk. This activity covers main flows related to butter production from cream. ;The process of buttermaking is basically a mechanical one in which cream, an emulsion of oil in water, is transformed to butter, an emulsion of water in oil. This is achieved by a process of batch or continuous churning.;The wet mass and water in wet mass is not balanced in this inventory because the emphasis was put on fat content balance.;Source: European Comission, IPPC, 2006, Reference Document on BAT in the Food, Milk and Drink Industries

This activity starts when the cream enters the dairy gate.

This activity end when the finished product - butter - is ready to leave the gates of the dairy. Packaging is not included in this inventory.
category: C:Manufacturing/10:Manufacture of food products/105:Manufacture of dairy products/1050:Manufacture of dairy products

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: A number of continuous techniques are available such as methods in which cream is subjected to high speed churning and continuous working. The main steps of buttermaking are always the same.  ;Scheme of butter manufacture from cream (EU Commission, IPPC, 2006, Reference Document on Best Available Techniques in the Food, Drink and Milk Industries).
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset was created based on literature data (Nilsson K., 2010, Comparative life cycle assessment of margarine and butter consumed in the UK, Germany and France) which present data collected at dairies in Denmark and Germany,

exchanges.description: Calculated based on dry/wet mass balance.

flow.name: buttermilk, from cow milk
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/10:Manufacture of food products/105:Manufacture of dairy products/1050:Manufacture of dairy products

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature value (Djekic, 2013, Environmental life-cycle assessment of various dairy products) the amount of milk needed to produce 1kg of cream is approximatelly 3.8kg. According to literature (Nilsson K., 2010, Comparative life cycle assessment of margarine and butter consumed in the UK, Germany and France) the amount of milk needed in order to produce 1kg of butter is 18.9kg. Thus the amount of cream needed to produce 1kg of butter is calculated to be 5kg.

flow.name: cream, from cow milk
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/10:Manufacture of food products/105:Manufacture of dairy products/1050:Manufacture of dairy products

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. 

Wastewater from potato starch production is a proxy for the wastewater from butter production for which data are not available.

The amount of wastewater is calculated as difference between the amount of tap water entering the process and the amount of water which is consumed in th process (evaporates).

Cross referenced; according to literature (Djekic, 2013, Environmental life-cycle assessment of various dairy products) the amount of wastewater produced when producing butter is between 6.41 - 9.61 l/kg.

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature value. According to literature (Djekic, 2013, Environmental life-cycle assessment of various dairy products) the amount of nitric acid needed for producing cream from raw milk is approximatelly 1% from the total amount of nitric acid needed when producing butter from raw milk. These 1% have been deducted in this exchange since the raw milk to cream step is not included in the bounderies of this activity.
